bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, September 19, 1923

div1.p: Kean seeks information on J.F. Binnie, an old acquaintance and a patient in Truby's hospital.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, September 19, 1923
div1.opener:
IN REPLY
REFER TO
HEADQUARTERS FIRST CORPS AREA
ARMY BASE
BOSTON 9. MASS,
September 19, 1923.
JRK/FM
Colonel Albert E. Truby, M.C.,
Letterman General Hospital,
San Francisco, Calif.
My dear Truby:
div1.p:
I heard some little while ago that my old friend, Lt. Colonel
J. F. Binnie, was ill in your hospital and in rather a helpless condi-
tion. I knew Colonel Binnie when I was stationed at Leavenworth in
1914-15 and am under great obligations to him for his goodness in coming up
very often to Leavenworth to see and operate on my son, Bob, when he
was very ill and came near dying with osteomyelitis of the hip joint
and tibia. I would be very glad if you would let me know what is his
exact condition and the prognosis in his case. Also let me know if
Mrs. Binnie is there with him and how she is.

Colonel Binnie did fine work in France in 1918 as Director
of a Base Hospital which he organized and took over, and then as con-
sulting surgeon of the First Army Corps. It was in connection with
this latter work that he broke down. I am sure from the fact that he
is in your hospital that you appreciate his fine services and are
doing everything you can for him.

Mrs. Kean and I often talk of our happy times with you and
Mrs. Truby and the girls in France two years ago. Please give them
my love.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. Kean. July - 1921
6 mo. HotSprings
July 22, LSh
Rt-
One arm placed
Rt Leg-
Complete amnesia for reading
almost complete " " speech
